channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Face-off in Chinese City Over Censorship of Newspaper
item.description: Protests at one of China’s most liberal newspapers pitted free speech advocates against supporters of Communist Party control who wielded red flags and portraits of Mao Zedong.
item.dc:creator: By JONAH M. KESSEL and CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:credit: Jonah M. Kessel for The New York Times
item.media:description: A free speech advocate outside of Southern Weekend newspaper in Guangzhou, China, on Tuesday.

item.title: In Clashes in Kashmir, Indians Claim 2 Soldiers Were Killed
item.description: The sudden surge in violence between Indians and Pakistanis is a troubling development in Kashmir, where a cease-fire has been in place for almost 10 years.
item.dc:creator: By DECLAN WALSH

item.title: American Delegation Arrives in North Korea on Controversial Private Trip
item.description: Eric Schmidt, Google’s executive chairman, arrived in North Korea on Monday with what was billed as a humanitarian mission.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: Eric Schmidt, Google's executive chairman, arrived in Pyongyang on Monday.

item.title: Trial Begins for April Casburn, Scotland Yard Officer, in Phone-Hacking Scandal
item.description: Detective Chief Inspector April Casburn is accused of seeking to sell confidential police information to a British tabloid owned by Rupert Murdoch.
item.category: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
item.dc:creator: By JOHN F. BURNS

item.title: Ivory Poachers Kill 11 Elephants in Park in Kenya
item.description: Kenyan officials discovered the carcasses of an entire elephant family in a national park, underscoring the danger poaching presents to the species but also the country’s economy.
item.dc:creator: By JEFFREY GETTLEMAN

item.title: Euro Watch: Unemployment Continues to Climb in Euro Zone
item.description: The jobless rate in the 17-nation bloc rose to 11.8 percent in November, a month in which German exports, imports and industrial orders all declined.
item.dc:creator: By MELISSA EDDY and DAVID JOLLY

item.title: Venezuelan Government: Hugo Chávez to Miss Scheduled Swearing-In
item.description: Due to health problems, Venezuelan President Hugo Chávez will miss Thursday’s scheduled swearing-in ceremony for his third term, the government said in a letter to Congress read out on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Aid Groups Report Rising Misery Among Displaced Syrians
item.description: A million Syrians are not getting enough to eat, the groups said, and in Jordan, violence broke out in a refugee camp in after a winter storm.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE and NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
item.media:description: Syrian refugees left their tents after heavy rain, at the Zaatari refugee camp in northern Jordan on Tuesday.

item.title: Chemical Weapons Showdown With Syria Led to Rare Accord
item.description: In a show of international cooperation that involved Russia and Iraq, Syria was persuaded to stop chemical bomb preparation. But the United States and Europe are not resting easy.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ERIC SCHMITT and DAVID E. SANGER
item.media:description: The violence in Syria continued on Monday. Above, Syrians went to the aid of a man who was wounded when a missile hit the al-Mashhad district of Aleppo.

item.title: Japan Summons China’s Envoy After Ships Near Islands
item.description: Chinese ships entered Japanese-controlled waters for 13 hours on Monday, near uninhabited islands also claimed by China and Taiwan.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER

item.title: China Says It Will Overhaul Re-education System
item.description: Legal advocates said an announcement fueled hopes that the draconian system of labor camps, established in the 1950s, would be significantly modified.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS

item.title: British Soldier Killed by Afghan Soldier on Base
item.description: The first insider attack of 2013 left six other British soldiers wounded at a small base in the south. The attacker was also killed.
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN and TAIMOOR SHAH

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Orthodox Leader Presses for More Adoptions
item.description: The patriarch of the Russian Orthodox Church encouraged Russians to adopt orphans, as the country adjusts to a decision to bar Americans from adopting Russian children.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY

item.title: Berlusconi Joins Coalition for Italy’s Next Election
item.description: Silvio Berlusconi agreed to back the Northern League’s federalist agenda and said he would not become prime minister if the alliance won.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: Huge Amounts Spent on Immigration, Study Finds
item.description: The Obama administration spent significantly more on immigration enforcement last year than on all the other major federal law enforcement agencies combined, a report says.
item.dc:creator: By JULIA PRESTON
item.media:description: A man suspected of being an illegal immigrant from Mexico was searched by a federal immigration officer in Phoenix last April.

item.title: Memo From Tel Aviv: For Netanyahu in Israel, Being in Front Has Risks
item.description: The presumption that Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel will win another term has led many of his supporters to flirt with smaller parties that cater to special interests.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN

item.title: Japan’s Cleanup After a Nuclear Accident Is Denounced
item.description: Much of Japan’s post-Fukushima cleanup is primitive, slapdash and bereft of the cleanup methods lauded by scientists as effective in removing radioactive cesium.
item.dc:creator: By HIROKO TABUCHI
item.media:credit: Ko Sasaki for The New York Times
item.media:description: Bags of contaminated soil outside the Naraha-Minami school near the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant.

item.title: The Lede Blog: American Missing in Iran Was Dressed Like Guantánamo Prisoner in Photographs Sent to Family
item.description: Robert Levinson, a former F.B.I. agent who went missing in Iran in 2007, was dressed like a prisoner at the American detention camp at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, in photographs sent to his family.
item.dc:creator: By BARRY MEIER
item.media:description: A photograph sent to the family of Robert Levinson in 2011, four years after the former Federal Bureau of Investigation agent went missing in Iran.

item.title: Iran’s Oil Exports and Sales Down 40 Percent, Official Admits
item.description: The oil minister, Rostam Qasemi, acknowledged that petroleum exports and sales had fallen by at least 40 percent over the past year, contradicting his previous denials.
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Official to Leave Panel Overseeing Delayed Berlin Airport
item.description: The announcement of Mayor Klaus Wowereit’s resignation from the board came as the project’s opening was pushed back for a fifth time.
item.dc:creator: By MELISSA EDDY

item.title: Oil Sand Industry in Canada Tied to Higher Carcinogen Level
item.description: Alberta’s oil sands industry has raised the levels of cancer-causing compounds in surrounding lakes well beyond natural levels, researchers reported.
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN
item.media:description: An oil sands mine Fort McMurray, Alberta.

item.title: WORLD: Halting Syria’s Chemical Weapons Effort
item.description: The Times’s David E. Sanger discusses the bid to keep the Syrian president, Bashar al-Assad, from using chemical weapons.

item.title: Videos of Chávez Promote Stability During Illness
item.description: As Hugo Chávez’s health presents political uncertainty, state television plays polished videos of the Venezuelan president in an apparent effort to reassure loyalists.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: In Caracas on Saturday, Venezuelans showed support for President Hugo Chávez, who is in Cuba after an operation.

item.title: Bahrain Court Confirms Jail Terms for 13 Dissidents
item.description: The court’s decision to uphold the convictions, government opponents say, is evidence of the monarchy’s resistance to a political solution.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM
item.media:description: Antigovernment protesters clashed Monday with riot police officers in Malkiya, a village on Bahrain’s west coast.

item.title: India Ink: In Maharashtra, Fight Over Restaurant Bill Erupts into Riot
item.description: Five killed from police fire and over 200 injured during riots in Dhule city, Maharashtra.
item.dc:creator: By NEHA THIRANI
